image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Australians will cast their first referendum vote in more than two decades in October, deciding the fate of a constitutionally-enshrined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

title.children: October 14 set as Voice to Parliament referendum

image.altText: A composite of photos of three people, two smiling. Two are men, and one is a woman.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announces a date for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: 'An important day': Australians have their say as Indigenous Voice referendum date is announced

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian Electoral Commissioner Tom Rogers is urging Australians to avoid misinformation when it comes to how to fill out their ballot paper. "I'm really urging everyone to write 'Yes' or 'No' in full on the ballot paper, and that way you can make sure your vote actually counts," he told the ABC. "The AEC is applying the law that parliament passed … I think at the last event the formality rate was 99 per cent of Australians, [who] wrote either Yes or No — so I'm urging Australians to do that for this event as well. "I'm even nervous talking about it, because every time I say it, it inflames an issue that's a non-issue even further."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electoral commissioner urges Australians to write 'Yes' or 'No' on their ballot

props.alt: A middle-aged white man in a suit with glasses.

children.content: Australian Electoral Commissioner Tom Rogers.
(ABC News)
Australian Electoral Commissioner Tom Rogers is urging Australians to avoid misinformation when it comes to how to fill out their ballot paper.
"I'm really urging everyone to write 'Yes' or 'No' in full on the ballot paper, and that way you can make sure your vote actually counts," he told the ABC.

"The AEC is applying the law that parliament passed … I think at the last event the formality rate was 99 per cent of Australians, [who] wrote either Yes or No — so I'm urging Australians to do that for this event as well.
"I'm even nervous talking about it, because every time I say it, it inflames an issue that's a non-issue even further."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Late last week the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) criticised some factually incorrect commentary in the media, which had suggested the organisation was preferencing the Yes vote by not counting votes when people write an X onto their referendum paper. The AEC says it is following a law which "is long-standing and unchanged through many governments, parliaments, and multiple referendums". "The longstanding legal advice provides that a cross can be open to interpretation as to whether it denotes approval or disapproval: many people use it daily to indicate approval in checkboxes on forms," it says. "The legal advice provides that for a single referendum question, a clear 'tick' should be counted as formal and a 'cross' should not. " Opposition leader Peter Dutton said the method "just stinks" and he would make his feelings known to the AEC. Speaking with ABC New Breakfast on Monday, Nationals leader David Littleproud also criticised the AEC's process and called for it to be reviewed. The AEC says only 0.86 per cent of votes in the 1999 federal referendum were informal, and many "would have had no relevance to the use of ticks or crosses".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How will tick (✔) or cross (✖) votes be treated by the Electoral Commission?

children.content: Late last week the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) criticised some factually incorrect commentary in the media, which had suggested the organisation was preferencing the Yes vote by not counting votes when people write an X onto their referendum paper.
The AEC says it is following a law which "is long-standing and unchanged through many governments, parliaments, and multiple referendums".

"The longstanding legal advice provides that a cross can be open to interpretation as to whether it denotes approval or disapproval: many people use it daily to indicate approval in checkboxes on forms,"
it says
"The legal advice provides that for a single referendum question,
a clear 'tick' should be counted as formal and a 'cross' should not.
Opposition leader Peter Dutton
said the method "just stinks"
and he would make his feelings known to the AEC.
Speaking with ABC New Breakfast on Monday, Nationals leader David Littleproud also criticised the AEC's process and called for it to be reviewed.
The AEC says only 0.86 per cent of votes in the 1999 federal referendum were informal
, and many "would have had no relevance to the use of ticks or crosses".

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A rally on Wall Street has sent Australian stocks higher, while inflation fell to 4.9 per cent in the year to July. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises as inflation cools to 4.9pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is still up at the middle of the trading day, and mining companies are continue to lead the gains. The benchmark ASX 200 index jumped 94 points or 1.3 per cent to 7,304 by 12:19pm AEST. Miners gained 1.5 per cent as China's move to boost affordable housing strengthened copper prices. Sector majors Rio Tinto and BHP jumped 2.1 per cent and 1.5 per cent, respectively. Healthcare and tech sectors also joined the rally, rising 1.6 per cent and 0.6 per cent, respectively. The energy sub-index rose 1.2 per cent as oil prices rallied, while investors debated the potential impact to energy supply and demand from Hurricane Idalia. Here are the top and bottom movers at midday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still tracking higher at lunch

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: But let's look beneath the headline inflation figure. According to the ABS, rent prices are now increasing at an annual rate of 7.6%, up from 7.3% in June, reflecting strong demand for rental properties and tight rental markets. That's occurring while the rate of increase in prices of new dwellings for owner occupiers continues to slow. They're now running at an annual pace of 5.9%, which is the lowest since October 2021.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rents increasing by 7.6%

children.content: But let's look beneath the headline inflation figure.
According to the ABS,
rent prices are now increasing at an annual rate of 7.6%
, up from 7.3% in June, reflecting strong demand for rental properties and tight rental markets.
That's occurring while the rate of increase in prices of new dwellings for owner occupiers continues to slow. They're now running at an
annual pace of 5.9%, which is the lowest since October 2021.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Statistics has just published its latest monthly consumer price index (CPI) indicator. It says inflation was running at an annual pace of 4.9% in July, down from 5.4% in June. And that's down from a peak of 8.4% in December. The monthly indicator is not as comprehensive as the quarterly inflation data because it doesn't capture 100% of the prices in the economy. However, economists say it provides a pretty good indication of how prices are behaving, so this will be positive news for the Reserve Bank.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation declines to 4.9%, according to monthly indicator

children.content: The Bureau of Statistics has just published its latest monthly consumer price index (CPI) indicator.
It says inflation was running at an
annual pace of 4.9% in July
down from 5.4% in June.
And that's down from a peak of 8.4% in December.
The monthly indicator is not as comprehensive as the quarterly inflation data because it doesn't capture 100% of the prices in the economy.
However, economists say it provides a pretty good indication of how prices are behaving, so this will be positive news for the Reserve Bank.
